comment.body: don't quite understand this: Where's the key material for composite, then?

pull_request.title: Implementation of Composite Sig
pull_request.body:
This is an implementation of the version 10 [Composite Signatures For Use In Internet PKI](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/draft-ounsworth-pq-composite-sigs/).
Current status of this work:
- I'm working on fixing the issues pointed by the Git Actions workflow tests.
- There will be alterations to update this for version 11 when it is released.
- To be precise with the IETF draft, we need to wait for ML-DSA-ipd to be implemented.

comment.body: Is this still accurate (issue seems closed)?

comment.body:
its in there, but the order is not the same, the hybrid will have Classic then PQ, Composite its the opposite, PQ then classic.
This "unless is composite" is referring to the point that the classic key will not be the first.

comment.body: It's rather obvious given the reference to Entrust' OID space, but in line with #351 would you mind putting a comment at the top of the file referencing yourself (or anyone else taking that responsibility) for keeping these OIDs in line with underlying spec/draft (referencing the latter, too)?

comment.body:
I followed the same pattern as the hybrid does, and the setECParams() is still used for the classical key recreate.
I didn't check if the setECParams() workaround is still accurate.
https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/oqs-provider/blob/main/oqsprov/oqsprov_keys.c#L533C1-L535C18
